content:
Hello there info 9068.

Your Windows PC, okay. okay the situation on your pc is as follows, that there can no longer be communicated between the two at the moment.

Going to the config editor in the option page on your PC and using it in conjunction with this fix, to avoid it in the future.

follow me. Open the Thunderbird window and go to tools)options)advanced)general)config editor.

Open the config editor , if possible type mailnews.tcptimeout in the search field as follows . right click on that row and select the change option in the gray bar.

now be in the about.config section and have this option selected.

change the Value to another number something like 1000 or 2000.

If your computer still sends you these messages after filling it in properly, there may be something wrong with your Internet or your own computer or a temporary timeout of our servers. The latter usually disappears after some time.


Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there


IMAP Your Name: How you want your name to appear in emails (example: Jane Test) Username/Email Address: Your full email address (example: test@example.com) Password: Your email password Incoming (Type): IMAP Incoming Server Hostname: imap.mydomain.com Incoming Port: 143 Incoming SSL: Your preference. If you choose SSL/TLS, have the incoming server, and port reflects their appropriate SSL settings. Incoming Authentication: We recommend Normal password. Outgoing Server Hostname: smtp.mydomain.com Outgoing Port: 587 Outgoing SSL: Your preference. If you choose SSL/TLS, have the outgoing server, and port reflects their appropriate SSL settings. Outgoing Authentication: We recommend Normal password



Imap reference for a Imap connection with Thunderbird software. Check the settings in the account if it looks simmilair.

content:
How do I turn the title bar back on in Tbird 115 in linux? Contrary to the OP's uninformed opinion, I find the ability to "shade window" with the title bars of my apps VERY, VERY useful for managing the multitude of windows open on my monitors (for the huge number of tasks I switch between).

In fact, my first reaction to getting an update to Tbird 115 was an audible "Oh, FSCK OFF Mozilla!". Thankfully, I work mostly alone in my own office.

My second was "Great! Now I'll have also have to troubleshoot the new behaviour I've been seeing in all my Windows users." -- where Tbird 115 appears to ignore the previously-effedtive userprefs.js directive: user_pref("mailnews.mark_message_read.auto", false);

But that's a different tar pit. Right now I want to know how to get my title bar back in Tbird 115. I do not see any way to do this in the "customize" menu, activated by right clicking on the menu bar(s).
creator: firefox-bisiSysadmin

content:
christ1 said
You can turn off the Title bar via Customize.

actually, in TBird 115 the title bar gets turned off as part of the update (stop messing with my carefully-tuned workspace!~).

fix it this way: In Settings (for the application, not the account) -> General -> Language & Appearance -> Window Layout. The default is changed (even for existing users!) to "Hide system window titlebar". Uncheck the box.

Just a little more detail for those who've not been using the tools long enough to know about "shade window" and how effective that can be for managing multitudes of long-lived application windows... XFCE4 -> Window Manager -> Advanced -> Double click action
creator: firefox-bisiSysadmin

content:
Derek Shaw said
... My second was "Great! Now I'll have also have to troubleshoot the new behaviour I've been seeing in all my Windows users." -- where Tbird 115 appears to ignore the previously-effective userprefs.js directive: user_pref("mailnews.mark_message_read.auto", false);

Can confirm ( it only took 6 minutes, after fixing the original issues) that TB 115, after update from TB102, now mis-behaves in Linux the same as it does in Windows - it ignores the FALSE setting for "Automatically mark message as read"

for those of you not using the more direct editing methods, that is now located at Settings (app, not account) -> General -> Reading and Display -> Automatically mark messages as read

The box is still unchecke, and yet the message gets marked as read after what appears to be a little more than 5 minutes. There are other confounding variables, like this being an IMAP server, and not a big commercial one like google, so it may not be a universal issue. But it is still a terrifically important change in behaviour, especially to some of my clients who have relied on this functionality for literally 20 years.

...and yes, I'll find the appropriate place to post the issue, with all the gory details -- AFTER I explain to the client that Mozilla has gone all Microsoft (and everybody else) on them, breaking their workflow due to some careless regression testing.
creator: firefox-bisiSysadmin

content:
Okay, you're upset. We understand. But please understand it's difficult to hear you because of the continuing growth of our user base. People like Thunderbird and a fair number donate regularly. Could it be better? Definitely. Have you seen the article produced by the developers on the need to rewrite old code and streamline Thunderbird? It is an encouraging and forward-thinking document that parallels some of what you write about, but with no indication of a removal of features. If you haven't seen it, the article as at https://blog.thunderbird.net/2023/02/the-future-of-thunderbird-why-were-rebuilding-from-the-ground-up/ Speaking just for myself, I acknowledge there are faster, smaller, email clients: a favorite is Becky! -- simple, small, does email and nothing else; and there is Sylpheed, a real speed machine; and Clawsmail is similar and supports HTML, also fast and small. But what they have in common is they each serve only a small niche of users.

I should add that this forum is administered by volunteers, people who have no voice in the code or its design, but who volunteer their time here to help other users. The comments in this post are just mine. I do not speak for the Thunderbird users, who each speak for themselves. If you want a discussion in-depth, you might want to consider posting your concerns at bugzilla dot mozilla dot org, or at connect dot mozilla dot org. Thanks for sharing your views. We agree on one thing at least: Thunderbird needs to get better and it's already on the way. The beta is a good sign of that.
creator: davidsk

content:
This might be an issue with Outlook - whilst some people are using Thunderbird, another person was accessing via gmail and also see same issue.

You say "Thunderbird 's option "Leave messages on server" is unchecked." So, that should send a delete signal.

You say " POP account - This means that every time I do "Get Messages ", I receive the same set of messages as last time. "

However, whether delete signal was sent or not would not mean you should get another download of same emails. This makes me wonder if you have an issue with the 'popstate.dat' file.


When emails are downloaded to a POP account, thunderbird keeps a record of what was previously downloaded in a 'popstate.dat' file, so when it checks the server Inbox on the next occasion, it does not download something previously downloaded.

In your case it seems to be failing which implies something is wrong with the 'popstate.dat' file.

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • Click on 'Mail' folder
  • Click on the pop mail account name folder

You should see one 'popstate.dat' file.

Do you see several files with similar name maybe with an additional number ? eg: popstate-1.dat

If that 'popstate.dat' file has got corrupted maybe it keeps recreating a new one, so it has no idea what was previously downloaded. The more common culprit for causing this problem is if you have something scanning profile eg: Anti-Virus and/or CCLeaner or WiseCleaner type programs which is deleting the popstate.dat file.

Advise: do not allow any scanning of Profile name folder by any product as it can cause havoc with files with session data etc. Make the thunderbird profile folder exempt from scanning.

Advise you delete any 'popstate.dat' or 'popstate-1.dat' files.

This means a new one will get created when you start Thunderbird and as it contains no data, it will cause a fresh download of anything in the server 'Inbox'.

Advise you logon to webmail account and remove all previously downloaded emails into another folder to prevent another download or do nothing and allow the full download.

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you are using a POP mail account: POP mail accounts can only access the server/webmail account 'Inbox' and download emails to the pop account 'Inbox'. Pop accounts do not synchronise with server folders. If server puts an email into the webmail 'Spam' folder then it is impossible for a Pop account to access that email because it is not in the webmail 'Inbox'. the only way you get to see emails that the server has put into other folder eg: Spam is to logon on to the webmail account via a browser and check the 'Spam' folder.

Perhaps there is a setting or filter which you can create in the webmail account forcing all emails to remin in the Inbox.


In Thunderbird. Pop accounts would see a 'Junk' folder. You would have to check the Pop accounts settings but they should look very similar to the imgae posted below. If you ever click on email and then select 'Junk' - that email will go into the Pop account 'Junk' folder.

I'm assuming you have set up anormal Pop mail account and not a deferred account aka a Global Inbox (Local Folders) account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Are you talking about CalDav Calendar ? check the option "Prefer client-side email scheduling", Does the info at this link help? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/enable-email-invitations-caldav-servers-configured
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: robert364

content:
Exit Thunderbird. Access Firewall: Do not switch off Firewall as that is not exactly ideal. Set up Thunderbird.exe as an allowed program - also set up the updater.exe as allowed as well. I've added an image below - I use Norton 360 - it shows the two items that are set up as allowed.

Now access the Anti-Virus product. You need to set up an Exception to allow this website: https://addons.thunderbird.net Avast and AVG are well known to be a pain if that is not set up.

Usual method to install addon.

  • Menu icon > Addons and Themes
  • Select the 'Extensions' option in left pane
  • In top search type name of addon and click on either the magnifying glass or press Enter key
  • List of possibilities should open in a new tab - virtually instantly.
  • For the addon you want - click on 'Add to Thunderbird'
  • Then you will get asked via a pop up to click on 'Add' and ok it.
  • It gets installed into Thunderbird and is seen in the Extenions list.

content:
When emails are downloaded to a POP account, thunderbird keeps a record of what was previously downloaded in a 'popstate.dat' file, so when it checks the server Inbox on the next occasion, it does not download something previously downloaded.

In your case it seems to be failing which implies something is wrong with the 'popstate.dat' file.

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • Click on 'Mail' folder
  • Click on the pop mail account name folder

You should see one 'popstate.dat' file.

Do you see several files with similar name maybe with an additional number ? eg: popstate-1.dat

If that 'popstate.dat' file has got corrupted maybe it keeps recreating a new one, so it has no idea what was previously downloaded. The more common culprit for causing this problem is if you have something scanning profile eg: Anti-Virus and/or CCLeaner or WiseCleaner type programs which is deleting the popstate.dat file.

Advise: do not allow any scanning of Profile name folder by any product as it can cause havoc with files with session data etc. Make the thunderbird profile folder exempt from scanning.

Advise you delete any 'popstate.dat' or 'popstate-1.dat' files.

This means a new one will get created when you start Thunderbird and as it contains no data, it will cause a fresh download of anything in the server 'Inbox'.

Advise you logon to webmail account and remove all previously downloaded emails into another folder to prevent another download or do nothing and allow the full download.

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall
